title: Event Manager Interview

title: Fundraising Events Manager Interview

title: Director of Fundraising Events Interview

title: Campaign Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 6 weeks. I interviewed at JDC (The Joint) (New York, NY) in Jun 2021

title: Marketing Copywriter Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at JDC (The Joint) (New York, NY) in Dec 2020
Interview Descriptions: In short, I was impressed. JDC was warm, respectful, and communicative throughout this entire process. HR is committed to finding the best talent, and so they take interviews very seriously--there are four stages, from the intro to the final meeting with management. Be sure to develop detailed answers that illustrate your ability to handle pressure, produce sharp content, and work across a wide array of mediums. The most difficult, but rewarding, part of the interview process is the marketing assessment, which tests your ability to produce compelling, on-brand content. Put everything into this test: It's the "hard" evidence that proves you're a creative, hard-working individual.
Interview Questions:
1) Tell us about yourself.

2) What is it about marketing that attracts you to this field? 

3) Why JDC?

4) Tell us about a time when you had to manage many different tasks.

title: Marketing Copywriter Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. I interviewed at JDC (The Joint) (New York, NY) in Nov 2020
Interview Descriptions: The interviewing process was extremely lengthy and time consuming. It took two whole weeks from each point of contact until they let me know I was moving ahead, and then another week to actually schedule the next interview.  My first point of contact was in the beginning of November and now it’s already the end of December.  My last phase of the process was to do a writing assessment that was supposed to take “just a few hours” and was given 3 business days to complete it. The assessment was to write three social media posts (for different platforms), a 5 paragraph story, headline three ads, optimize two blog posts for SEO, come up with follow up questions, and explain my strategy behind all of it. I am used to working in a fast paced marketing agency, so I know that turnaround times for all of these projects together are approx 1.5-2 weeks.  I bent over backwards to finish it all on time. They told me 2 days after submitting the assessment that they don’t want to move forward. I enjoyed the people I met, but as you can see, there were many red flags about this interview process that lead me to think that I probably wouldn’t be happy working there.
Interview Questions: How did you get into copywriting and marketing?

title: Sr. Development Officer Interview
Application Type: I applied through other source. I interviewed at JDC (The Joint) (Sharon, MA) in Oct 2020
Interview Descriptions:
1st Round: HR

3rd Round: Heads of the Department

title: Knowledge Management Specialist Interview

Interview Descriptions: Initial phone screen interview with HR followed by longer in depth interview with program director and head of HR. Very straight forward. Largely focused on my qualifications for the job, related experience, and explanation of the position itself.
Interview Questions: What experience do you have with knowledge management?

title: Executive Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 months. I interviewed at JDC (The Joint)
Interview Descriptions:
I applied to JDC back in December and received an invitation to interview after a couple of weeks. The first interview was over the phone with a recruiter. The recruiter was very friendly and helpful, however, the next time I heard back from JDC regarding the role was two months later. I had forgotten about the role/company as I got caught up in my current role and suddenly I received an email asking if I remember interviewing with them and if I'm still interested in continuing to the next step. I accepted to continue and had my second interview in person at the location (this was in February). 

At the second interview, one of the interviewers couldn't make it so she scheduled another video interview a week apart from the second one. After about two weeks from the video interview I was asked to complete a written assignment which consisted of creating an itinerary, creating a powerpoint about the organization, sending a mock email to a potential donor, creating some excel report on budgets, and sending screen shots of multiple entries into Google or Outlook calendar, and one other task. Although the interview process was extremely disorganized until this point,I had already spent so much time with the company  so I decided to do the tasks to see where this was going. 

After submitting the tasks, I was invited for another in person interview at the location (this time with three of the higher level executives). I felt good about the interviews and the direction this was going and was convinced this would be my last step in the process. I took the day off of work at my current role and attended the interview which was about 1.5 hours. After the meeting, I was told I would hear a decision by the end of the week. The recruiter then asked me to submit references as they were doing reference checks on all final candidates. I went through and contacted all my references to ask if I could put them down, and then submitted my references. 

A week went by and I didn't receive any information. I asked one of my references if anyone from the organization had contacted her and she told me they didn't. I waited another week and around the last day of the second week I received an email stating that there was another internal candidate that applied and that they would have to explore the possibilities more. I was understanding because of course, things like that can happen and I let them know I'd be willing to wait. 

About two weeks later, I received another email from the internal recruiter stating that they MIGHT be closing the role and that they're not sure yet so they will keep me updated in a couple more weeks. I was pretty confused at that point, because I'm not sure how it went from having all these interviews, to another internal candidate applying, to then having the role about to be closed? Like there was no sign of this beforehand? 

Anyway, about two weeks later I received another email stating that they are sure the role would be closed and that they would contact me in the future if anything opens up. 

Got called a few weeks later for a contract/temp role and they asked me to come in to interview again. I really wanted to see where this was going and had nothing to lose so I attended. Funny enough I knew this would happen at the end they emailed me and said they decided to go with another candidate. 

Everyone I met was extremely nice but I feel like the organization really needs to work on its public relations and recruiting practices. I should have known not to go along in their interview process but it was a good lesson for me nonetheless to not allow companies/organization to take advantage.
Interview Questions: How do you deal with competing tasks?

title: Marketing Coordinator Interview

Interview Questions: What do you know about JDC's work and how can you contribute to it in this role?

title: Resource Development Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at JDC (The Joint) (New York, NY) in Apr 2019
Interview Descriptions: Applied for different role originally, email sent requesting a phone interview and to schedule utilizing scheduling website. After 2-3 weeks sent an email stating "I believe this position is a better fit" and completed yet another phone interview answering the exact same questions from the first phone call. A few days later received phone call and email stating I was selected for next round interview with the VP of Resource Development in NYC,  had interview followed the next week by a video interview with Talent Acquisition Specialist from the initial phone interviews for a cultural interview regarding supervisor expectations and the team one would be a part of. Interview tone was very casual and left in a positive manner of offer being extended within next 3 days. 3 days later received a few missed calls from JDC with no voicemails left (unprofessional in my opinion as there were multiple missed calls, not a singular call). Reached out next day to talent acquisition specialist regarding the missed calls and given the typical "we have gone with another candidate and thank you for you time" At time of this review, the posting for the position is still listed online which is indicative that A) Specialist was dishonest in saying they had offered another candidate, rather than professional declining due to other issues, or B) Role is actively available to which I'd graciously await a call making an offer after the positive tone and positioning the specialist made at conclusion of interviews that she was beyond excited and prepared to have offer to last of finalists in upcoming days.
Interview Questions: What type of management style do you work best under?

title: Director of Marketing Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at JDC (The Joint) (New York, NY) in Apr 2019
Interview Descriptions: The interview process was multi-layered, starting with intro recruiter call, a call with the deputy director + in person with recruiter, and culminated with a 4 hour in-person interview with a 30-60-90 day presentation and discussions with a few team members. Each step of the interview process encouraged you to think broadly and holistically about the role, and demanded one to think creatively, analytically, and experientially.  Ultimately, I didn't get an offer, despite what I felt was a very positive, engaging, and energetic final round, and I can't say that I'm not disappointed or a bit shocked, but ultimately the company chose to go in a different direction and that's ok. It doesn't change how I feel about the company or the interview process -- overall, it was incredibly pleasant and enjoyable, and one would be so lucky to receive an offer.
Interview Questions: The final stage will be an in-person interview where we would like you to present a 30/60/90 day plan highlighting what you would do in your first 30, 60, and 90 days in the Director of Marketing role with Entwine.

title: Project Coordinator Interview

After the initial interview with HR, I was invited for a 2-hour interview in the New York office, which consisted of 4 separate interviews. A week later, I was invited for additional video interviews with team leadership. This was followed by an operations test, with spreadsheet and correspondence activities. Finally, I interviewed with a partner nonprofit philanthropy group who would be funding part of my position. All in all, very professional and cordial relations with HR and the team.

title: Global Jewish Service Corps Interview

Interview Descriptions: First there was an essay application, then a skype interview, then a group interview.  They flew everyone on the West Coast out to their office in San Diego, where we did a series of camp-like activities and presentations. Many questions were repeated over the various interviews. The entire process seemed very unorganized.
Interview Questions: Tell us about a challenge you faced in your workplace and how you were able to overcome it.

title: Global Service Fellow Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at JDC (The Joint) (New York, NY) in May 2012
Interview Descriptions: First submitted application the day it was due. Then had a skype interview--with pretty straightforward, behavioral-type questions. Then was flown in for the group interview day--with around 30 or 40 people. That was somewhat hectic but fun. A lot of different, interesting people. I only had one in-person interview, which lasted half an hour. There were also a number of group exercises. After the group interview day, I had a couple of phone interviews. Then they thought of placing me elsewhere, so I interviewed a couple times with my potential supervisors. It was lengthy process but not difficult. Questions were straightforward, interviewers nice. And props to the NY office for reading my application and thoughtfully considering the best location to place me.
Interview Questions: Nothing unexpected. You talk about yourself and your previous experience. Prepare to explain how you deal with challenges--you confront a lot of challenges as a JSC Fellow.

title: Global Service Fellow Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 months. I interviewed at JDC (The Joint) (New York, NY) in Apr 2012
Interview Descriptions: The interview process was comprehensive- a Skype interview, then an all-day in-person interview, and then another phone interview with a potential supervisor. The all-day interview was intense, but the phone conversation with the supervisor was most important in securing the position, because they wanted to know that I would really fit with my supervisor.
Interview Questions: How do you handle new situations?

title: Global Jewish Service Corps Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at JDC (The Joint) (New York, NY) in Mar 2012
Interview Descriptions: There was a written application with multiple questions. A short skype interview followed. Then there was a group interview where they brought all finalists to New York. Finally, there was a placement interview
Interview Questions: What is a verse or teaching that is very important to you?
